rSESNx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Outside the Coastal Plain this species can be found on dry rocky slopes of sparsely wooded oak-pine and mixed oak pine woodlands (Mitchell 1994, NatureServe 2005). ******Hand Modeling: DO NOT use landform restrictor within the Coastal Plain. Also to get more at open woodlands, use Forest interior layer as an AVOID MASK. 25Aug05  Buffer based on mobility, could not find any information regarding home range or daily movement.

references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.B72MIN01NAUS: Minton, S. A., Jr. 1972. Amphibians and reptiles of Indiana. Indiana Academy Science Monographs 3. v + 346 pp.
references.B89DUN01NAUS: Dundee, H. A., and D. A. Rossman. 1989. The amphibians and reptiles of Louisiana. Louisiana State Univ. Press, Baton Rouge.
references.B90COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1990. Standard common and current scientific names for North American amphibians and reptiles. SSAR Herpetol. Circular No. 19. 41 pp.
references.A82TEL01NAUS: Telford, S. R., Jr. 1982. Tantilla coronata. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 308.1-308.2.
references.B80MAR01NAUS: Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
references.W12NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.B75MOU01NAUS: Mount, R. H. 1975. The Reptiles and Amphibians of Alabama. Auburn University Agricultural Experiment Station, Auburn, Alabama. vii + 347 pp.
references.B97TEN01USGP: Tennant, A. 1997. A field guide to snakes of Florida. Gulf Publishing Company, Houston, Texas.  257 pp.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.B71BAR01NAUS: Barbour, R. W. 1971. Amphibians and reptiles of Kentucky. Univ. Press of Kentucky, Lexington. x + 334 pp.
references.B95PAL01NAUS: Palmer, W. M., and A. L. Braswell. 1995. Reptiles of North Carolina. North Carolina State Museum of Natural Sciences, University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina.
references.B81ASH01NAUS: Ashton, R. E., Jr., and P. S. Ashton. 1981. Handbook of Reptiles and Amphibians of Florida. Part One:The Snakes. Windward Pub. Co., Miami, Florida. 176 pp.
references.B94MIT01NCGP: Mitchell, J. C. 1994. The reptiles of Virginia. Washington, DC: Smithsonian Institution Press.
references.B01MIN01USGP: Minton, S. A., Jr. 2001. Amphibians & reptiles of Indiana. Revised second edition. Indiana Academy of Science, Indianapolis.
references.B03ERN01USGP: Ernst, C. H., and E. M. Ernst. 2003. Snakes of the United States and Canada. Smithsonian Books, Washington, D.C.

habitat_description:
This species occurs from western Kentucky and extreme southern Indiana eastward to Virginia, south to portions of eastern Louisiana, Alabama, and the Florida panhandle (Ashton and Ashton 1981; Dundee and Rossman 1989; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Minton 2001; Mitchell 1994; Palmer and Braswell 1995).

Burrowing takes place in or using soil, leaf litter, or fallen logs. During the day, this species is found under rocks, debris, or similar surface cover. Also under decaying logs and stumps. At night, it wanders into onto roads. Eggs are usually laid in rotting logs, underground, sawdust piles, under woody debris (Natureserve.org). Populations are generally found in dry and wooded pine or oak woodland, containing an abundance of rocks, logs, and decaying stumps. Habitats can be located on hillsides and ridges, sandy pine flatwoods, maritime forests, sandhills, mesic meadows, hardwood hammocks, and margins of swamps, marshes, and rivers (Ashton and Ashton 1981; Barbour 1971; Dundee and Rossman 1989; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Minton 2001; Mitchell 1994; Mount 1975; Palmer and Braswell 1995; Tennant 1997).


SE-	Plant communities are often characteristic of xeric pine woodland, mesic meadows, oak woodland, and hardwood hammocks. However, important features of these environments are rocks, debris, and decaying stumps.
